double_jeopardy_round: CITY OF THE DAY: SAN FRANCISCO

(1, 1).clue: This Philippine city was proclaimed a capital on June 24, 1571 & again on June 24, 1976

(2, 1).clue: In December 2005 an estimated 13.5 million late-night viewers tuned in to see him welcome Oprah to his show

(3, 1).clue: The peen is opposite the striking surface on this tool

(4, 1).clue: New to Museum Mile, the Neue Galerie features works from Austria & this country, home of Ernst Kirchner

(5, 1).clue: This British sport features 2 teams of 11 members & 2 wickets placed 22 yards apart

(1, 2).clue: June is Dairy Month in this 30th state & celebrates its proud dairy heritage

(2, 2).clue: In 2004 this "X-Files" star disappeared behind the camera to direct his first movie, "The House of D"

(3, 2).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew inserts a Phillips-head screwdriver into a screw.)  With its quick alignment, the Phillips-head screw was designed to help in mass production; it first became standard in this industry

(4, 2).clue: 5 of the fewer than 40 known Vermeers reside in this 5th Avenue museum

(5, 2).clue: Battledore & shuttlecock was the forerunner of this racket game

(6, 2).clue: Now it's a party!  Here's Joe with this "pony" cask of ale

(1, 3).clue: The National Foundation for this June holiday is based in Baltimore

(2, 3).clue: In 1988 he won a Pulitzer Prize for his humorous newspaper columns

(3, 3).clue: Someone with an ulterior motive "has" this tool "to grind"

(4, 3).clue: The exterior of this museum at 5th & 89th was designed to break the rectangular grid of Manhattan

(5, 3).clue: It's the trademarked name for the game that uses a hollow white celluloid ball that's 40 mm in diameter

(6, 3).clue: A rounded mass of chewing gum

(1, 4).clue: Famous date on which more than 5,000 ships carrying Allied troops crossed the English Channel

(2, 4).clue: With 6 Major League teams including the Padres & Yankees, he hit 465 home runs & won 7 Gold Gloves

(3, 4).clue: The saw, an ancient tool, was first patented in this shape by Samuel Miller in 1777

(4, 4).clue: The Museum of the City of N.Y. has the derby of this governor, the first Catholic to be a major party pres. candidate

(5, 4).clue: A fronton is the arena in which this sport is played

(6, 4).clue: Over there; often hitched with hither

(1, 5).clue: Declared a public enemy by the Senate, this Roman emperor committed suicide on June 9, 68 A.D.

(2, 5).clue: Take five & name this leader of the jazz quartet heard here

(3, 5).clue: A sickle is a crescent-shaped blade on a short handle; this is a long, single-edged blade on a long, curved pole

(4, 5).clue: A Latino art museum goes by the name El Museo del this, a Spanish word for the inner city

(5, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew plays croquet.)  In U.S. croquet, a ball that goes through all the wickets has this travelling name, especially if it's the red one

(6, 5).clue: When paired with vigor, it signifies exuberance

(1, 1).clue: Members of the American Indian movement seized this then-unoccupied island in 1969 & were forced off in 1971

(2, 1).clue: In a way, this show whose theme is heard here was 12,000 years in the making

(4, 1).clue: If someone wants you caught & is offering a reward, you have this "on your head"

(5, 1).clue: E.-C. Genet, an 18th c. French minister to the U.S., undermined the neutrality policy of this pres., who got him recalled

(6, 1).clue: This antonym of "to mark" is a synonym of "efface" & rhymes with it

(1, 2).clue: (Jon of the Clue Crew reports from Chinatown in San Francisco.)  The first of San Francisco's Chinese immigrants arrived on the ship Eagle in 1848, a week after this discovery that changed California

(2, 2).clue: 1971--those were the days for this show

(4, 2).clue: Merv could tell you this monster who drew the chariot of the sun may come from Indo-Iranian mythology

(5, 2).clue: Vijaya Pandit saw both sides of the Cold War as ambassador of this country to the U.S. & USSR in the 1940s

(6, 2).clue: The traditional mark of someone who can't sign his name has this opposite in tic-tac-toe

(1, 3).clue: This poet was the first black--& the first female--streetcar conductor in San Francisco

(2, 3).clue: This sitcom's theme song is heard here

(2, 4).clue: I'm so glad you had the time to tell me this zany variety show whose theme is heard here

(3, 4).clue: Robin Hood's pseudonym in "Ivanhoe", or Tennyson's "Hall"(8)

(4, 4).clue: 18th century English writer Samuel & a motel-chain founder both had this last name

(5, 4).clue: Carlos de Icaza, ambassador from this country, attended the 2005 inauguration of the new mayor of Los Angeles

(2, 5).clue: Stand back!  It's the '70s action series whose theme is heard here

(0, 0).clue: It's the only state that doesn't have an undergraduate university or university system named just for the state itself
